questions.text: A man had GI fluid loss for which he was being given oral rehydration solution. Glucose absorption from his gut will utilise which of the following transporters?
questions.solution:
• Glucose and galactose are transported from the intestinal lumen into the cells by a Na+ dependent cotransport (SGLT1) in the luminal membrane. The sugar is transported "uphill" and Na + is transported "downhill."
  • are then transported from cell to blood by facilitated diffusion (GLUT2).
  • The Na+ -K + pump in the basolateral membrane keeps the intracellular [Na+ ] low, thus maintaining the Na + gradient across the luminal membrane
  • DEFECT in SGLT-1 causes Glucose and Galactose Malabsorption Syndrome.

questions.text: Following are the levels of various ions in a body fluid. Identify the fluid Na+= 10mEq/L, K+= 140mEq\L, Cl-=15mEq/L, HCO3-=12mEq/L
questions.solution:
• Sodium ions, chloride ions and bicarbonate levels are high in the ECF.
  • Potassium level is high in the intracellular fluid
  • Level of potassium ions in ECF is around 140 meq/liter

questions.text: Tetany will result from which of the following disorder?
questions.solution:
TETANY is seen in:

  • Alkalosis
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

During hyperventilation CO2 will be washed out. Greater amount of the calcium will bind with plasma proteins (albumin). Therefore patients with respiratory alkalosis are more susceptible for hypocalamic tetany.

While in acidosis, less calcium bind with plasma proteins so more free calcium

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with the following cardiovascular findings : large 'a' wave on JVP , mid diastolic murmur , Pedal Edema ++. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The combination of the clinical signs described here - large 'A' wave on JVP, a mid-diastolic murmur, and pedal edema - points towards Mitral Stenosis (MS).

  • Large 'A' wave on JVP: This suggests increased atrial pressure, which is commonly seen in mitral stenosis due to impaired left ventricular filling and backflow into the left atrium during ventricular contraction.
  • Mid-diastolic murmur: This is characteristic of mitral stenosis, which causes turbulent blood flow across the mitral valve during diastole.
  • Pedal edema: This is a sign of congestive heart failure, which is commonly seen in patients with mitral stenosisdue to left-sided heart failure leading to systemic congestion.

Mitral Stenosis (MS) is a condition where the mitral valve becomes narrowed, causing obstruction to blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle. This leads to increased left atrial pressure, pulmonary congestion, and right heart failure, resulting in symptoms like pedal edema. The large 'A' wave and mid-diastolic murmur are hallmarks of this condition.

Jugular venous pulse (JVP):

  • a wave-atrial contraction. Prominent in AV dissociation (cannon a wave) and tricuspid stenosis, absent in atrial fibrillation.
  • c wave-RV contraction (closed tricuspid valve bulging into atrium).
  • x descent-atrial relaxation and downward displacement of closed tricuspid valve during rapid ventricular ejection phase. Reduced or absent in tricuspid regurgitation and right HF because pressure gradients are reduced.
  • v wave- ↑RA pressure due to ↑volume against closed tricuspid valve.
  • y descent-RA emptying into RV. Prominent in constrictive pericarditis, absent in cardiac tamponade.

Incorrect Options:

Option B : Tricuspid Stenosis (TS) - Tricuspid stenosis can cause a jugular venous pressure (JVP) 'a' wave and edema, but the mid-diastolic murmur is less characteristic. Tricuspid stenosis also does not typically lead to pedal edema as significantly as mitral stenosis does.

Option C : Mitral Regurgitation (MR) - Mitral regurgitation typically presents with a holosystolic murmur rather than a mid-diastolic murmur. Although MR can cause left-sided heart failure and pedal edema, the large 'A' wave on JVP is less prominent in MR compared to MS.

Option D : Tricuspid Regurgitation (TR) - Tricuspid regurgitation often causes jugular venous distension with a prominent 'V' wave but does not typically cause the mid-diastolic murmur seen in mitral stenosis. Pedal edema can occur, but TR usually presents with a more distinct pattern of symptoms related to the right heart failure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mitral Stenosis (MS) presents with a large 'A' wave on JVP, mid-diastolic murmur, and signs of congestion such as pedal edema.
  • Mid-diastolic murmurs are commonly associated with MS, and this is crucial in differentiating it from other valvular disorders like MR or TR.
  • Pedal edema is a result of congestive heart failure, often a complication of MS.

questions.text: Neurological examination of a patient revealed the following Diplopia and suspected involvement of other cranial nerves, tingling and numbness in the lower extremities. Symptoms were getting worse upon taking hot bath. Defect of which of the following cells is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Oligodendrocytes are responsible for producing and maintaining myelin in the central nervous system (CNS). The patient's diplopia (cranial nerve involvement), sensory symptoms (tingling, numbness), and worsening with heat (Uhthoff's phenomenon) strongly suggest demyelination, commonly seen in Multiple Sclerosis (MS). MS is an autoimmune disorder characterized by loss of oligodendrocytes, leading to impaired nerve conduction.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Ependymal Cells: These line the ventricles and produce cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Damage to these cells is associated with hydrocephalus or CSF flow obstruction, not demyelinating diseases.

Option C: Astrocytes: Provide support, maintain the blood-brain barrier, and regulate ion balance. They are involved in reactive gliosis (scar formation) in MS but are not the primary cells affected.

Option D: Microglia: These are the immune cells of the CNS, responsible for phagocytosis and inflammatory responses. While they play a role in MS-related neuroinflammation, the primary defect in MS is oligodendrocyte destruction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Oligodendrocytes produce CNS myelin; their loss causes MS.
  • MS presents with diplopia, sensory deficits, and worsening with heat (Uhthoff's phenomenon).
  • Other glial cells (ependymal, astrocytes, microglia) have different CNS functions and are not the primary cause of demyelination.
